body:
:-1: for the inclusion in core for the following reasons:

1. can we officially maintain this for the next few years? - i assume not.
2. at least i can't this test for security since i'm not willed to register an account thereâ€¦
3. if we implement this i'm pretty sure there will be other peoples who implement other backends which they want to have merged in core and we have to support it then...
4. owncloud !== "owncloud hosted by rapidshare"

there is already a lot of unmaintained stuff - i don't want to add potential more things... sorry.

\cc @deepdiver1975 @karlitschek @icewind1991 @raydiation @mtgap

i like the idea but we sry @crazyphil we're going in the direction of splitting up the apps repo (mail app has already an own repo, others will follow) into multiple repositories. 

you can easily host your app on apps.owncloud. :-1:

@crazyphil i think this is very cool. thanks a lot for doing this. we don't want to support this officially in the core because of several reasons. but this doesn't meant that thas is not a cool feature that people should be able to use. i suggest that you take the existing files_external app and copy it as files_external_rapidshare that could be hosted in the apps repository or someone else. this app should be installable additionally to the files_external one. so it should only support the rapdishare protocol. you can make this app available via apps.owncloud.com if you want.
please let me know if you have any more questions.

@lukasreschke:
to 1., 2. and 3.: i fully understand that this addition means more work to support and maintain for the owncloud team. i didn't especially like the idea of putting it into the core either. i also considered @karlitschek's idea of creating an own app, but that's not an ideal solution. this means having multiple copies of various files that generally provide the same functionality, and in the worst case they are on different versions and patch levels.

a perfect solution would be an extendable files_external plugin, where the different backends are hosted as "standalone" apps, which simply integrate into the core plugin. this would allow easier integration of new backends (which is your concern no. 3) and it would also take the burden of supporting and maintaining them away from the core developers.

to 4.: i can't really follow this objection, because the files_external plugin already allows, for example, "owncloud hosted by amazon s3". i don't simply see this plugin's purpose as a way to quickly access one or two files on one's dropbox account, but more as a way to productively integrate external storage providers.

anyway, thank you all for the feedback. i will try to restructure the code for a standalone app until there might come a time where this is not necessary anymore.

not sure if we already need an additional layer here that abstracts the functionallity. this would make the files_external app even more fragile. and we already ave plenty of bugs here. i think that just a plain and stupid copy is not the worst solution for now. and when we see that this is actually working and people like it and perhaps more protocols show up that we should think about creating an abstraction here. i find this a bit early now :-)

i agree with @karlitschek but it depends on how much code can be shared or if its hard to implement this without additional code from the files_external app. i'd suggest to first evaluate the option carefully.

:-1: i don't see the need to have this in core as well. 
as a 3rdparty app maintained outside of the community effort i don't care.

we have already plenty of code to take care off.

and to be honest: how needs rapidshare? we better fix the rest.

@crazyphil app dependencies should come along with #1235 so, it should be fine to have the backends registering themselves. i suggest you wait until after owncloud 5 is released and everything settles done before opening another pull request. in the meantime, please be patient and test owncloud 5 ;)
